SB1003.title: Development projects.
SB1003.author: Tim Grayson
SB1003.summary: An act to amend Section 65940.1 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 12.
Referred to Com. on RLS.

analysis.notes: Modifies development project approval procedures to restrict local conditioning authority and impose state timelines on city review, mirroring AB2750.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1003 adds state procedural requirements to development approvals, limiting conditions cities may apply and shortening the time available for local deliberation.
• Limits local conditions: restricts legitimate protective conditions cities attach to housing approvals, reducing mitigation authority for project impacts
• Mandatory timelines: short state deadlines for local response reduce capacity for thorough technical review, especially in complex or contested projects
• Compressed appeals: abbreviated local appeal processes limit community challenge opportunities for residents affected by nearby development decisions
Recommended: CSF should oppose; engage city engineers and attorneys to document workability concerns and impacts on local capacity.

AB1751.title: Missing Middle Townhome Ownership Act.
AB1751.author: Sharon Quirk-Silva
AB1751.summary: An act to add Section 65852.29 to, and to add Chapter 9 (commencing with Section 66499.45) to Division 2 of Title 7 of, the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 12.

analysis.notes: Creates a statewide ministerial pathway for townhomes on any residential parcel, directly preempting local zoning and eliminating all discretionary review; cities cannot require impact fees or infrastructure improvements for new townhome residents.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB1751 (Missing Middle Townhome Ownership Act) creates a statewide ministerial pathway for townhome development on any residential parcel, overriding local single-family zoning without community input.
• Cities lose all discretionary authority — projects meeting state objective standards must be approved regardless of neighborhood character, infrastructure capacity, or local planning
• Eliminates design review and public hearings for qualifying developments; no CEQA review applies
• No impact fee authority: cities cannot charge water, sewer, traffic, or school impact fees for new townhome residents — infrastructure costs shift entirely to existing taxpayers
• Sets a precedent for further ministerial preemption of residential zoning across the state
Recommended: CSF should actively oppose; submit formal comment letters and coordinate with planning directors to document infrastructure and service capacity concerns.

SB1014.title: Development projects: onsite and offsite improvements.
SB1014.author: Tim Grayson
SB1014.summary: An act to add Sections 65913.3.2 and 65941.3 to the Government Code, relating to development projects.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 13.
Referred to Coms. on L. GOV. and HOUSING.

analysis.notes: Directly restricts cities' authority to require offsite infrastructure improvements as development conditions; prevents cities from ensuring new development funds its own traffic, utility, and safety impacts, shifting costs to existing residents and general fund.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1014 restricts cities' ability to require offsite infrastructure improvements as conditions of housing approvals, preventing communities from ensuring development pays for its own impacts.
• Limits infrastructure nexus: cities cannot fully require traffic, utility, or safety improvements connected to new development even when the nexus is clear
• Cost-shifting to taxpayers: existing residents bear infrastructure costs that new development should fund — a fundamental inequity the bill codifies
• Fair-share principle undermined: the longstanding principle that growth should pay for growth-related improvements is restricted by this legislation
Recommended: CSF should oppose; partner with public works directors to document infrastructure funding gaps created by improvement requirement restrictions.

AB1997.title: Land use: housing development approvals: timelines and processes.
AB1997.author: Alex Lee
AB1997.summary: An act to amend Sections 65589.5, 65589.9, and 65950 of, and to add Section 65943.3 to, the Government Code, and to add Section 50411 to the Health and Safety Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 20.

analysis.notes: Imposes mandatory state timelines on local housing approval processes and creates penalty exposure for cities that fail to meet them, subordinating local deliberation to a state-driven schedule.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB1997 forces compressed state timelines onto local housing approval processes and creates penalty risk for jurisdictions that cannot meet them, regardless of project complexity or local circumstances.
• Cities face consequences for legitimate review delays — environmental complexity, infrastructure concerns, and legal analysis all require time this bill restricts
• Eliminates meaningful public participation: shortened timelines reduce community input opportunities for residents affected by nearby development
• Imposes compliance and legal costs on cities that must track, document, and defend timeline adherence
• Disproportionate burden on small cities and counties with limited planning staff capacity
Recommended: CSF should oppose; advocate for reasonable local review timelines that protect thorough deliberation and document fiscal impacts on member jurisdictions.

AB2005.title: Housing developments: urban lot split: parcel maps.
AB2005.author: Patrick Ahrens
AB2005.summary: An act to amend Section 66411.7 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 20.

analysis.notes: Extends SB 9 urban lot split rights, enabling ministerial subdivision on single-family parcels with no local approval authority; cities cannot require infrastructure improvements or charge impact fees to fund water, sewer, and traffic capacity for new lots.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2005 expands SB 9 urban lot split rights, allowing ministerial parcel divisions in single-family zones and removing all local subdivision control over qualifying applications.
• Cities have zero authority to deny qualifying lot splits — foundational local subdivision powers are preempted by state objective standards
• Pairs with SB 9 to allow up to 4 units on formerly single-family lots without any local review
• Infrastructure burden: no impact fee authority for lot splits; water, sewer, and traffic costs for newly created parcels shift entirely to existing infrastructure and ratepayers
• Enforcement burden: cities must litigate objective standard disputes without clear resource support
Recommended: CSF should oppose; document infrastructure capacity gaps and engage legislators on workability amendments that preserve local infrastructure review.

AB2058.summary: An act to amend Section 19991.1 of the Health and Safety Code, relating to housing.

analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 21.

analysis.notes: Creates ministerial approval for adaptive reuse conversions, bypassing local zoning; cities have indirect infrastructure burden as converted buildings may strain existing utility capacity without local authority to require upgrades.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2079 establishes ministerial approval for adaptive reuse conversions, overriding local use designations and removing city authority to evaluate compatibility or impose conditions.
• Allows residential conversion regardless of local general plan or zoning — commercial and mixed-use areas designated for other purposes cannot prevent qualifying conversions
• Eliminates design review: cities cannot impose aesthetic, scale, or neighborhood compatibility requirements on converted structures
• Environmental concerns: hazardous materials, noise, and air quality issues on conversion sites may not trigger local protective review
Recommended: CSF should seek amendments preserving local compatibility review and environmental protections; monitor implementation for community impact in affected neighborhoods.

AB2110.title: Local financing: workforce housing: tax increment financing district.
AB2110.author: Natasha Johnson
AB2110.summary: An act to amend Section 53993 of, and to add Chapter 2.8.5 (commencing with Section 53397.50) to Part 1 of Division 2 of Title 5 of, the Government Code, relating to local government finance.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 21.

analysis.notes: Authorizes new tax increment financing districts for workforce housing, diverting local property tax revenue from general city services to state-directed housing priorities.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2110 creates new tax increment financing districts for workforce housing, conditioning their formation on state housing compliance and diverting local tax revenues from city services.
• Diverts property tax revenue: TIF allocations reduce funds available for police, fire, parks, libraries, and other community services
• State control over local fiscal tool: TIF authority is conditioned on housing compliance, limiting local budgetary flexibility and decision-making
• Precedent risk: expands TIF beyond redevelopment context into general housing compliance, creating new fiscal obligations tied to state mandates
Recommended: CSF should oppose unless local governing boards retain full discretion over TIF formation and allocation without state compliance conditions.

AB2118.title: Affordable Housing and High Road Jobs Act of 2022: use by right: objective standards.
AB2118.author: Josh Hoover
AB2118.summary: An act to amend Sections 65912.101 and 65912.123 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 21.

analysis.notes: Requires by-right approval for 'high road' affordable projects, removing local discretion; indirect infrastructure burden as ministerial approval limits cities' ability to require infrastructure improvements as approval conditions.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2118 mandates ministerial approval for affordable housing projects certified under 'high road' employment criteria, removing local discretion regardless of site context or community concerns.
• Eliminates local project review: qualifying projects receive ministerial approval regardless of neighborhood character, infrastructure capacity, or local planning context
• Ambiguous 'high road' criteria create inconsistent application and limit local ability to challenge compliance claims
• Sets precedent for further use-by-right expansions tied to state employment policy compliance
Recommended: CSF should seek amendments restoring objective standards review; oppose if the by-right provision cannot be narrowed to preserve meaningful local authority.

AB2127.title: Accessory dwelling units.
AB2127.author: Natasha Johnson
AB2127.summary: An act relating to land use.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 21.

analysis.notes: Further restricts local ADU standards and explicitly limits impact fee authority, preventing cities from charging water, sewer, traffic, and school fees needed to fund infrastructure for new ADU residents.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2127 further restricts local ADU regulations, limiting cities' ability to apply lot coverage, setback, and height standards that protect neighborhood character and infrastructure.
• Restricts objective development standards: cities cannot apply lot coverage, setback, and height standards that reflect local neighborhood character and topography
• Ministerial approval required: no local discretion over qualifying ADU applications regardless of site constraints or cumulative neighborhood impacts
• Infrastructure burden: cumulative ADU additions strain water, sewer, and parking capacity with cities losing fee authority to fund needed improvements
• Continues a pattern of incrementally removing all remaining local ADU authority through successive legislation
Recommended: CSF should oppose; advocate for local infrastructure impact fee authority to accompany ADU mandates; document service capacity deficits.

AB2185.title: Local planning: housing element.
AB2185.author: Sharon Quirk-Silva
AB2185.summary: An act to amend Section 65581 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 22.

analysis.notes: Expands housing element requirements and reporting mandates, increasing state oversight of local planning processes and creating additional compliance obligations.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2185 adds new requirements to local housing elements and expands HCD's ability to find cities out of compliance, increasing builder's remedy exposure and unfunded compliance costs.
• Adds mandated plan content: cities must include additional analysis, programs, and commitments that expand HCD oversight leverage over local planning documents
• Builder's remedy risk: expanded compliance standards increase the circumstances under which cities lose local zoning authority for housing projects
• Unfunded mandate: additional planning staff time and consultant costs with no accompanying state funding to offset the burden on cities
Recommended: CSF should seek funding provisions for all compliance costs; oppose any provisions expanding builder's remedy exposure or HCD override authority.

AB2252.title: Housing: Single stair entry and exit.
AB2252.author: Alex Lee

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 22.

analysis.notes: Modifies state building code to allow single-staircase buildings up to six stories, overriding local fire safety authority and enabling significantly higher density; taller buildings intensify demand on utilities, emergency services, and schools without local capacity review.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2252 changes the state building code to allow single-staircase buildings up to six stories, overriding local fire safety standards and enabling density levels cities have not chosen to permit.
• Overrides local fire and building safety authority: cities cannot impose stricter staircase requirements without a state variance process — local fire chiefs' concerns are preempted
• Enables higher density building types in neighborhoods where local plans designate lower density residential uses, bypassing community planning processes
• Infrastructure strain: taller buildings with more units intensify demand on utilities, streets, emergency services, and schools without local capacity review
Recommended: CSF should oppose or seek amendments preserving local fire authority override; engage fire chiefs, building officials, and emergency services agencies on safety implications.

AB2288.title: Adaptive reuse: industrial zones.
AB2288.author: Sharon Quirk-Silva
AB2288.summary: An act to amend Sections 65658.1 and 65658.5 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 22.

analysis.notes: Forces cities to allow residential conversions in industrial zones, preempting employment land protections; industrial zones lack residential utility infrastructure and cities cannot require developers to fund water, sewer, pedestrian, or parks upgrades needed for residential occupancy.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2288 forces cities to allow residential conversions in industrial-zoned areas, directly preempting employment land protections that communities have established through local planning.
• Preempts industrial land use designations: cities lose authority over employment zone preservation, undermining economic development strategies and tax base
• Threatens jobs and economic development: converting industrial to residential removes land cities rely on for tax-generating employment — a one-way transition with no reversal
• Infrastructure mismatch: industrial zones lack residential utilities, parks, and pedestrian infrastructure — cities cannot require developers to fund the needed upgrades for livable residential use
• No local environmental review: conversions proceed ministerially even on sites with contamination history or incompatible adjacent operations
Recommended: CSF should strongly oppose; partner with economic development organizations and labor groups on employment land preservation advocacy.

AB2295.title: Regional housing need: affordable housing.
AB2295.author: Natasha Johnson
AB2295.summary: An act to add Section 65584.2.3 to the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 22.

analysis.notes: Modifies RHNA methodology to increase affordable housing allocations to cities, raising compliance obligations and builder's remedy exposure for communities falling short.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2295 modifies regional housing needs methodology to increase the number of affordable units cities must plan for, raising RHNA numbers and expanding builder's remedy risk.
• Higher RHNA allocations force cities to rezone more land — often in established neighborhoods — through a process controlled by regional councils, not local voters
• Builder's remedy exposure: communities that cannot demonstrate adequate sites lose all local zoning authority for housing projects until compliance is restored
• Unfunded mandate: additional rezoning, EIR preparation, and HCD review cycles impose significant costs on cities with no accompanying state funding
Recommended: CSF should engage in RHNA methodology proceedings; oppose unfunded allocation increases and advocate for local infrastructure capacity as a factor in allocations.

AB2320.title: Multifamily Housing Program: Homekey: adaptive reuse.
AB2320.author: Tri Ta
AB2320.summary: An act to amend Section 50675.1.3 of the Health and Safety Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 22.

analysis.notes: Expands Homekey adaptive reuse funding conditioned on local streamlining that waives discretionary review; ministerial approval prevents cities from requiring utility upgrades, accessibility improvements, or neighborhood infrastructure as conditions of conversion approval.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2320 expands Homekey to adaptive reuse projects and conditions state funding on local approval streamlining, using the grant as a lever to extract local zoning concessions.
• State funding conditioned on local streamlining: receiving Homekey dollars requires cities to waive discretionary review, transforming a funding program into a preemption mechanism
• No local design authority: adaptive reuse projects funded through Homekey cannot be conditioned on neighborhood compatibility or safety standards
• Infrastructure conditions waived: Homekey streamlining prevents cities from requiring utility upgrades, accessibility improvements, or neighborhood infrastructure as approval conditions
• Precedent: links state housing dollars to local control preemption across a growing range of project types, normalizing coercive grant conditions
Recommended: CSF should seek amendments decoupling streamlining conditions from grant eligibility; monitor Homekey site selection for compatibility and community impacts.

AB2342.title: Housing development: transit-oriented development.
AB2342.author: Josh Hoover
AB2342.summary: An act to amend Section 65912.157 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.
From printer. May be heard in committee March 22.

analysis.notes: Expands TOD by-right zones and mandates ministerial approval for qualifying housing near transit, removing local authority over design and infrastructure conditions; accelerated TOD density proceeds without transit capacity improvements or utility upgrade requirements.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2342 expands transit-oriented development zones and mandates ministerial approval for qualifying housing within them, removing local planning authority over broad areas.
• Expands by-right zones: larger areas around transit stops lose local zoning authority — a broad transit definition means even low-frequency bus stops can trigger preemption
• Complete removal of local discretion: no hearings, design review, or conditions may be imposed on qualifying TOD projects regardless of neighborhood context
• Infrastructure disconnect: state-mandated densification near transit does not guarantee transit capacity, utility infrastructure, or school capacity improvements
• Scope creep: 'transit proximity' definitions can expand over time, extending preemption to progressively larger portions of cities
Recommended: CSF should oppose or seek strict frequency/ridership thresholds; document infrastructure gaps in existing TOD zones before expansion proceeds.

AB2390.title: Streamlined housing approvals: hazardous waste sites.
AB2390.author: Pilar Schiavo
AB2390.summary: An act to amend Section 65913.4 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Mandates ministerial approval for housing on remediated hazardous waste sites, removing local health and safety authority; indirect infrastructure burden as brownfield conversions may require utility and remediation infrastructure cities cannot condition.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2390 mandates ministerial housing approval on former hazardous waste sites, preventing local governments from imposing protective conditions or conducting independent health review.
• Removes local health and safety override: cities cannot deny housing on contamination sites even if remediation is incomplete, contested, or based on state determinations cities dispute
• Public health risk: ministerial approval on brownfield sites eliminates cities' ability to impose protective conditions for the safety of future residents and nearby community members
• Liability exposure: cities granting required approvals on hazardous sites may face future liability for health impacts without having had authority to impose protective conditions
Recommended: CSF should strongly oppose; partner with public health advocates and environmental justice organizations to document risks of removing local health oversight.

AB2433.title: Housing development: affordable homes bonus.
AB2433.author: David Alvarez
AB2433.summary: An act to amend Section 65915 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Expands Density Bonus Law, requiring higher density entitlements and further restricting objective standards cities may apply; density bonus projects can challenge infrastructure conditions as 'unduly restrictive,' preventing cities from requiring utility or traffic improvements.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2433 expands the Density Bonus Law to require cities to permit significantly more units than local zoning allows and further restricts the standards cities may apply to bonus projects.
• Higher density mandates: cities must permit significantly more units than their zoning provides — density limits negotiated through community planning processes are superseded
• Restricted objective standards: cities cannot apply design, massing, or compatibility standards that 'unduly constrain' bonus projects — an ambiguous standard that invites litigation
• Infrastructure cost-shifting: bonus project applicants can challenge infrastructure conditions as 'unduly restrictive,' preventing cities from requiring water, sewer, and traffic improvements
Recommended: CSF should oppose expansion provisions; engage with HCD on objective standards guidance that preserves meaningful local design and infrastructure review.

AB2480.summary: An act to amend Section 65915 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Extends density bonus protections to student housing near campuses, requiring ministerial approval and higher density entitlements; ministerial framework prevents cities from requiring infrastructure improvements to serve increased density near campuses.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2480 extends density bonus rights to student housing near campuses, mandating ministerial approval and higher density entitlements in neighborhoods cities may have planned for lower density.
• Campus adjacency preemption: neighborhoods near colleges and universities lose local density controls for student housing, regardless of neighborhood character or infrastructure capacity
• Ministerial approval: no local discretionary review of scale, design, or neighborhood impact for qualifying projects — community concerns cannot be conditions of approval
• Definition risk: broad 'student housing' definitions could extend protections to projects not primarily serving students, expanding preemption scope
Recommended: CSF should seek objective standards review amendments and campus coordination requirements; oppose ministerial provisions that remove all local authority.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Amends housing element law to expand HCD oversight and compliance requirements, increasing state scrutiny of local plans and builder's remedy exposure.

• Unfunded mandate: additional findings, studies, and consultation requirements imposed without state funding to offset the added burden on city planning departments
Recommended: CSF should oppose provisions expanding HCD override authority; advocate for adequate funding to accompany any new requirements.

AB2601.title: Planning and zoning: housing development: streamlined approval and subdivisions.
AB2601.author: Alex Lee
AB2601.summary: An act to amend Sections 65852.21, 65852.28, 65913.4.5, 66411.7, and 66499.41 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Omnibus streamlining bill consolidates ministerial approval pathways across multiple code sections, preventing cities from requiring infrastructure mitigation conditions on a broad range of projects; multi-provision changes create significant unfunded compliance burden on local planning departments.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2601 is an omnibus streamlining bill that consolidates and expands ministerial approval pathways across multiple code sections — one of the broadest single-bill local control preemptions.
• Broadens by-right approval across multiple project categories: the cumulative effect eliminates local review authority for a large share of new housing applications
• Amplifies existing preemption statutes: layering new provisions on top of existing streamlining creates compounded loss of local control that is difficult to reverse
• Infrastructure impact unchecked: ministerial approvals across multiple code sections prevent cities from requiring infrastructure mitigation — shifting utility, traffic, and capacity costs to communities
• Compliance complexity: multi-provision changes create significant legal uncertainty and costly implementation burden for local planning departments
Recommended: CSF should strongly oppose; this is a high-priority bill for coordinated advocacy with planning directors, city attorneys, and the League of California Cities.

AB2676.title: Housing Crisis Act of 2019.
AB2676.author: James Gallagher
AB2676.summary: An act to amend Section 66300 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Modifies the Housing Crisis Act to extend anti-downzoning restrictions and further limit cities' ability to reduce residential capacity or update plans in response to changed conditions.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2676 extends Housing Crisis Act provisions that lock cities into current residential zoning levels, preventing planning updates that reflect changed conditions or community priorities.
• Prohibits downzoning: cities cannot reduce zoning capacity even for legitimate planning, environmental, safety, or community character reasons — General Plans are frozen in place
• Undermines General Plan updates: communities cannot revise plans in ways that reduce residential density even with strong community support for doing so
• No off-ramp: Housing Crisis Act restrictions have no expiration or local override mechanism, permanently constraining future planning choices
Recommended: CSF should oppose; engage with Planning Directors Association to document specific cases where the anti-downzoning prohibition creates planning harms.

AB2741.title: Housing element: inventory of land: substantial compliance.
AB2741.author: Al Muratsuchi
AB2741.summary: An act relating to housing elements.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Modifies housing element 'substantial compliance' standards in ways that lower the threshold for HCD non-compliance findings and expand builder's remedy exposure.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2741 lowers the housing element 'substantial compliance' bar, making it easier for HCD to find cities non-compliant and expose them to builder's remedy loss of local zoning authority.
• Lower compliance threshold: changes to substantial compliance rules make it easier for HCD to reject housing elements that reflect genuine community planning choices
• Builder's remedy risk: non-compliance findings strip cities of zoning authority for all housing projects — one of the most severe local control losses in state law
• Retroactive risk: 'substantial compliance' changes may apply to already-certified housing elements, destabilizing planning processes cities have already completed
• Unfunded compliance burden: additional documentation and legal review required with no state funding to offset costs on city planning departments
Recommended: CSF should oppose; seek grandfather provisions for certified elements and coordinate with city attorneys on legal exposure.

AB2750.title: Development projects.
AB2750.author: Jesse Gabriel
AB2750.summary: An act to amend Section 65941.1 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Read first time. To print.

analysis.notes: Modifies state development project approval procedures to restrict local conditioning authority and impose state-mandated timelines on city review processes.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
AB2750 adds state procedural requirements to development project approvals, restricting the conditions cities may apply and compressing local deliberation timelines.
• Restricts local conditions: limits the types of protective conditions cities can attach to housing and development approvals, reducing cities' ability to mitigate project impacts
• Mandatory response windows: state-set deadlines reduce deliberative review time, particularly for projects with complex environmental or infrastructure issues
• Shifts appeals balance: modifications to local appeal processes favor applicants over community members who may be impacted by nearby development
Recommended: CSF should oppose; document cases where local conditions protect public health, safety, and community character from development impacts.

SB1116.title: Planning and zoning: housing development projects: subdivisions.
SB1116.author: Anna Caballero
SB1116.summary: An act to amend Sections 65400, 65852.28, and 66499.41 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 20.

analysis.notes: Creates ministerial subdivision approvals that prevent cities from requiring frontage improvements, utility upgrades, or traffic mitigation as subdivision conditions; compliance with new ministerial framework requires significant unfunded planning department resources.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1116 mandates ministerial approval for qualifying subdivision projects — one of the most significant local preemptions because subdivisions are foundational local planning decisions.
• Ministerial subdivision approvals: cities lose discretionary authority over subdivision design, lot layout, and compatibility with surrounding development
• Removes CEQA applicability for qualifying projects: environmental review that enables community input and identifies cumulative impacts is eliminated
• Infrastructure burden: subdivisions approved ministerially cannot be conditioned on frontage improvements, utility upgrades, traffic mitigation, or school capacity — existing residents absorb costs of new development
• Cumulative impact: subdivision approvals affect multiple parcels and permanently shape neighborhood character — removing local authority is irreversible
Recommended: CSF should strongly oppose and prioritize for coalition advocacy with planning agencies, environmental groups, and the Planning Directors Association.

SB1117.title: Accessory dwelling units and junior accessory dwelling units.
SB1117.author: Sabrina Cervantes
SB1117.summary: An act to amend Section 66311.5 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 20.

analysis.notes: Further restricts local ADU regulations and explicitly eliminates remaining impact fee authority, preventing cities from charging the infrastructure fees needed to serve new ADU residents.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1117 is another in a long series of bills eliminating remaining local ADU authority, this time targeting objective standards and fee provisions cities still retain.
• Eliminates fee authority: cities cannot charge the impact fees that fund water, sewer, traffic, and school capacity needed to serve new ADU residents
• Restricts remaining objective standards: further limits the design, setback, and height standards cities may apply — including standards that protect solar access and fire safety
• No capacity management: removes remaining local tools for managing cumulative growth in neighborhoods already experiencing infrastructure stress
• Permanent preemption pattern: each successive ADU bill removes another layer of local authority with no restoration mechanism in state law
Recommended: CSF should oppose; document infrastructure funding deficits created by ADU fee elimination and coordinate with other municipal leagues on ADU advocacy.

SB1145.title: Affordable Housing and Sustainable Communities Program.
SB1145.author: Tim Grayson
SB1145.summary: An act to amend Section 75215 of the Public Resources Code, relating to greenhouse gases.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 21.

analysis.notes: Expands the Affordable Housing and Sustainable Communities Program in ways that condition local streamlining obligations on state climate-transportation funding.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1145 expands AHSC program funding conditions that require local approval streamlining as a grant condition, using climate funding as a lever to extract local zoning concessions.
• Coercive funding condition: receiving AHSC grants requires local streamlining that overrides normal planning review — a quid pro quo that makes preemption the price of state dollars
• Climate/housing linkage: state climate policy becomes a mechanism for expanding local housing preemption beyond what the legislature has directly enacted
• Transit proximity override: neighborhoods near transit lose planning authority on AHSC-funded projects with no community input mechanism
Recommended: CSF should seek amendments decoupling streamlining conditions from grant eligibility; engage with transportation agencies on preserving local planning integrity.

SB1196.title: Accessory dwelling units.
SB1196.author: Jerry McNerney
SB1196.summary: An act to amend Section 66313 of the Government Code, relating to land use.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 22.

analysis.notes: Extends ADU preemptions to cover standards that survived previous legislation; fee restrictions prevent cities from funding water, sewer, and service capacity for ADU residents.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1196 amends ADU law to close remaining gaps in local authority, preempting specific standards that cities have retained and expanding ministerial approval to new situations.
• New targeted preemptions: specifically overrides local standards that have survived previous ADU legislation — a deliberate effort to eliminate all remaining local ADU authority
• No local safety override: cities cannot impose additional safety conditions even where local fire or building officials have identified specific site-level concerns
• Service burden without revenue: ADU residents use city services but fee restrictions prevent cities from collecting funds to maintain or expand those services
• Cumulative preemption: alongside SB1117 and AB2127, represents a coordinated effort to entirely remove local ADU authority in a single legislative session
Recommended: CSF should oppose; coordinate with other municipal leagues on a unified ADU preemption response; prioritize for joint advocacy with League of California Cities.

SB1216.title: Planning and Zoning Law: housing leadership designation.
SB1216.author: Christopher Cabaldon
SB1216.summary: An act to add Section 65589.10 to the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 22.

analysis.notes: Creates a state 'housing leadership' designation for cities that adopt state-favored housing policies, creating tiered compliance pressure that stigmatizes local planning choices.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1216 creates a state housing leadership designation that uses reputational pressure to coerce cities into adopting state housing priorities over local planning choices.
• Stigmatizes local planning choices: cities prioritizing neighborhood character, infrastructure adequacy, or community process are implicitly labeled as 'non-leaders'
• Pressure-based coercion: reputational incentives push cities to adopt policies they might otherwise reject through legitimate deliberative planning processes
• Competitive dynamic: leadership criteria create pressure among neighboring jurisdictions to preemptively adopt state mandates to avoid being labeled non-compliant
Recommended: CSF should oppose the framework and engage with legislators on alternative recognition systems that respect and celebrate diverse local planning approaches.

SB1229.title: Coastal resources: coastal development permits: disaster exemption.
SB1229.author: Benjamin Allen
SB1229.summary: An act to amend Section 30610 of the Public Resources Code, relating to coastal resources.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 22.

analysis.notes: Expands disaster exemptions from coastal development permit requirements, reducing coastal commission and local oversight of rebuilding in sensitive coastal areas.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1229 broadens exemptions from coastal development permits in disaster zones, reducing local and state oversight of rebuilding activities in environmentally sensitive coastal areas.
• Reduces environmental review: exemptions from CDP requirements limit analysis of cumulative coastal impacts and climate resilience considerations for rebuilt structures
• Local agency notification rights reduced: coastal cities lose input authority over otherwise-exempt rebuilding that affects their shoreline character and public access
• Climate risk precedent: expedited rebuilding in coastal hazard zones without full permit review may create long-term safety issues as sea levels rise
Recommended: CSF should monitor and seek amendments preserving local notification rights and safety review for rebuilding in sensitive coastal and hazard areas.

SB1258.title: Streamlined housing approvals: hazardous waste sites.
SB1258.author: Scott Wiener
SB1258.summary: An act to amend Section 65913.4 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Introduced. Read first time. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.
From printer. May be acted upon on or after March 22.

analysis.notes: Companion to AB2390 — mandates ministerial housing approval on brownfield sites, bypassing local health and environmental oversight; indirect infrastructure burden as contamination sites may require specialized utility and remediation infrastructure.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1258 (companion to AB2390) mandates ministerial housing approval on brownfield sites, eliminating cities' authority to protect future residents and neighbors from contamination risks.
• Overrides local health review: cities cannot impose protective conditions or deny housing on remediated sites even if local officials have concerns about remediation adequacy
• State-determined 'clean': remediation determinations rest with state agencies, bypassing local environmental expertise and community health knowledge
• Public health liability: ministerial approval on contaminated sites creates risk for future residents and nearby community members without any local oversight mechanism
• Dual-bill risk: SB1258 and AB2390 advancing simultaneously amplifies this preemption — at least one is likely to pass even if the other is amended
Recommended: CSF should strongly oppose both SB1258 and AB2390; coordinate with health departments and environmental justice advocates; prioritize for coalition testimony.

SB1344.title: Civil actions: housing development projects.
SB1344.author: Christopher Cabaldon
SB1344.summary: An act to amend Section 529.2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, relating to civil actions.

actions.description: Introduced. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.

analysis.notes: Restricts injunctive relief in housing development litigation, limiting local governments' and communities' ability to pause harmful projects pending legal review.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1344 restricts injunctive relief in housing development litigation, preventing local governments and community members from pausing harmful projects while courts review them.
• Restricts injunctive relief: cities and community groups cannot as readily pause projects with legal defects while litigation proceeds — the harm may be done before courts rule
• Chills local enforcement: risk of losing injunctive protection deters cities from enforcing legitimate planning requirements against well-funded developers
• Weakens CEQA community protection: injunctive relief is a primary tool for communities to pause projects pending environmental review — this bill directly undermines that protection
• Legal cost burden: cities must continue defending while unable to pause development, increasing litigation costs with no interim protection
Recommended: CSF should oppose; engage with local attorneys and CEQA practitioners on litigation strategy and connect with environmental justice advocates on shared concerns.

SB1383.title: Housing development projects: postentitlement phase permit.
SB1383.author: Jesse Arreguin
SB1383.summary: An act to amend, repeal, and add Section 65913.3 of the Government Code, relating to housing.

actions.description: Introduced. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.

analysis.notes: Mandates state-paced timelines for post-entitlement building permits and inspections; cities face penalties for delays even from workload or safety complexity; requires significant unfunded staffing increases to meet mandatory timelines.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — D criterion reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1383 imposes mandatory state timelines on local building permits and inspections, preventing cities from managing workload and ensuring safety and code compliance.
• Mandatory building permit timelines: cities face penalties for review delays even when driven by project complexity, incomplete submissions, or public safety concerns
• Inspection timeline mandates: local inspectors must meet state windows regardless of workload, staffing constraints, or priority calls on public safety resources
• Unfunded compliance mandate: additional inspection and permit staffing required with no accompanying state funding — a direct financial burden on local governments
Recommended: CSF should oppose or seek workload capacity amendments; document disproportionate impact on smaller jurisdictions and cities with older housing stock.

SB1415.title: Real property tax: welfare exemption: moderate-income housing.
SB1415.author: Jesse Arreguin
SB1415.summary: An act to amend Section 214 of the Revenue and Taxation Code, relating to taxation, to take effect immediately, tax levy.

actions.description: Introduced. To Com. on RLS. for assignment. To print.

analysis.notes: Expands the property tax welfare exemption to moderate-income housing, reducing local property tax revenue without providing cities a mechanism to offset the fiscal loss.
analysis.model: claude-sonnet-4-6 (via Claude Code) — local control risk reanalysis
analysis.comms_brief:
SB1415 extends property tax welfare exemptions to moderate-income housing (80-120% AMI), reducing local government revenue with no local opt-out or offset mechanism.
• Direct fiscal impact on cities and special districts: property tax exemptions reduce revenue available for police, fire, schools, parks, and other community services
• No local opt-out: cities cannot decline the exemption even if the fiscal impact is significant for their budget — state tax policy overrides local fiscal decision-making
• Precedent for expansion: widening the welfare exemption to moderate-income housing establishes a pathway for further revenue-reducing expansions
Recommended: CSF should oppose or seek local fiscal impact provisions and local opt-in/opt-out authority for affected jurisdictions.
